headline: Gutfeld on Trump's all-caps tweet
subHeadline: Trump responds to Iran's president and predictably the media freak out.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, THE FIVE CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and a peanut shell is her bike helmet, Dana Perino. 'The Five.' Last night, President Trump tweeted a reminder to Iran not to mess with us. It was in all caps. Showing the world that he's not afraid to go all caps. What's next? If you listen to the media, it has to be war. Fact is, Trump was just responding to the Iranian president who warned us about a mother of all wars. Remember the last guy who said that? Yet, predictably, the media freaks out, forgetting that whole North Korea thing which followed the same pattern. So forgive me I, unlike CNN, I'm not pulling my hair out. So, I'll take a war of words over a war of worlds. Now, the media claims this tweet is a distraction from last week's summit. Yet, how did that summit hurt Trump? For all the media shaming he's at 45 percent approval, that's his highest so far. And we're happier with the country's direction than any time in the last eight years. This confuses the media, as they keep saying that Trump is the worst thing to ever happen since 'The View.' There're going to be consequences going forward with how the administration deals with the regime, and they're obviously looking at the idea of Iran not being able to sustain economically any kind of sanctions or further pressure the United States puts on them because it will lead to regime change which the U.S. is not officially pushing for, but based on the things that have been said, the pressure that have been put on, Pompeo calling out the leaders by name and saying that they're hypocritical holy men and tweeting in Farsi to the activists on the ground there. Now, this is an overall strategy for the administration. It's not just a distraction from Russia, because we've been dealing with this even before Trump became president on the campaign trail.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Does anybody like the mullahs? In Iran, I mean, the people -- I mean, how much sway do they have?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: With the military, right? That they get the goodies, right? It's just a typical dictatorial regime. I think the other thing that we forget is that in Afghanistan and in Iraq, in particular, Iraq is actually doing much better from a law and governance standpoint, but Iran is causing additional problems and they're moving into Afghanistan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I think you forget though that there's a counter to the U.S. sanctions. I think U.S. sanctions, Katie, are going to have some pain -- caused some pain for the Iranians. But, don't forget, the other parties in what was a six party agreement on the Iranian deal are still in it, still doing business. In fact.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and they're prompting up the terrorist regime.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not arguing that point with you. I would agree that they are terrorists. But I would say this that the U.S. -- the United States acting unilaterally we are becoming more isolated and weak around the world stage. We should have our allies with us going against the Iranians. We shouldn't be separated out so that we can be identified by the mullahs as just the big bad Americans who think they're going to run the world. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK. So do you think the president's tweet was strong or weak?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it was a distraction from all of his trouble with the Russians in Helsinki.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wait, we want to pull back yet we want to run the world. How is that possible?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's leading from behind. That's what he's trying to do, lead it from behind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If he was that subtle, I would tip my cap to him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You'll be tipping your cap soon. All right. The president looking to strip security clearances from top anti-Trump Obama intel officials. That's the latest, next. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: President Trump is threatening to pull the security clearances of several former top Obama intelligence officials including James Comey, John Brennan, James Clapper, Andrew McCabe, Susan Rice, and Michael Hayden, the White House accusing them of politicizing or monetizing their former positions and making baseless claims about President Trump. Here are just some recent examples of their attacks.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BRENNAN, FORMER CIA DIRECOTR
utterances.sentences: What Mr. Trump did yesterday was to betray the women and men of the FBI, the CIA, NSA and others, and to betray the American public. And that's why I use the term that this is nothing short of treasonous.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I really do wonder whether the Russians have something on him.

utterances.speaker: SUSAN RICE, FORMER NSA ADVISER
utterances.sentences: The policies that this president has pursued globally have served Vladimir Putin's interests.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTORO
utterances.sentences: I think he's morally unfit to be president. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. All right. So, Dana, will this actually have an impact on these players at all, or is this kind of like a public humiliation?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's the latter. Like -- or a political, you know, retaliation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: For retaliation. If any of them were actually going back to the agency and getting a security briefing and then using that knowledge to get money off of it inappropriately, that would be a violation that the Department of Justice should look into. And I don't think that's actually the accusation being made here. I'm assuming it is because they've gone out and done books and had TV contracts or things -- or get speeches, and people think they know things, like McCabe is not a good example because his security clearance was deactivated when he was like -- or from the FBI. Hayden tweeted that he's never actually gone back and have a security briefing. I'm assuming that the Trump officials are actually not briefing people like Susan Rice, and Clapper, and Brennan. So, I think that it's a little bit -- looks like political retaliation. Probably good for fodder, but the practical result, not much.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Great for fodder, right, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm a big fan of fodder. Just dropped into our show. How does Brennan have a security clearance? A guy who's as trustworthy as Jesse's barber. But I agree with you, Dana. This really is sent to you the more of it. It's like, OK. So you're saying we're colluding? Well, we're going to say you're colluding. It's, again, it's like tic-tac-toe. It's like Rochambeau. Everybody is like coming at each other. But I do agree that I think that -- you can disagree with the administration, but I think they've ventured into undermining it, right? They have. I mean, come on, when you call the president a traitor, treasonous, you're undermining it. Take away his clearance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yep. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Debrief him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What if you're speaking the truth?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What -- it doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: but even if this happens to them, I don't think they're going to change anything that they say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, but the thing is -- I mean, you've made all the key points. They're not actually being briefed. I mean, this people were in the intelligence community. So I think this fits into a narrative from President Trump that would say these are the citizens of the deep state and they hate me. They've been trying to beat me during the campaign. They're still trying to undermine me. The problem with the argument is, one, if you really want to know somebody who is do upped the dirty deeds with actual intelligence, how about Michael Flynn? That was your national security advisor, Mr. President. And, secondly, hey, what about people like Will Hurd who was a CIA agent, now in the congress, a Republican who says he thinks that you are being used by President Putin? What about, you know, people like Bryan Fitzpatrick, Mike Rogers, these are good Republicans who say something odd is going on between the Russians and President Trump. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's more than just, you know, retribution against what you call the deep state, Juan. Some of the things that they've said have been outrageous, as Greg mentioned. But, also, now that you have the FISA warrant of Carter Page released, Katie, that shows extreme abuse of the system. They did not disclose that it was funded by the DNC.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, what are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did not disclose.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was funded by Hillary. It did not, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And this was never verified at all, any of this information. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is not true, America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, I read the whole thing. Did you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I saw -- in fact, not only that, I had to discuss it on 'Fox News Sunday' with people like.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Was the dossier the primary element in obtaining the warrant, Juan? The number one element on the dossier was right there in front of the judge and they did not disclose it was funded by Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They did. They said it was funded by his political opponent, Jesse. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was funded by a candidate, Juan. A candidate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In that case, did you read and see that it didn't even name Donald Trump? He's just candidate one who becomes president, did you notice that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, if you're going to lie to a FISA judge.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And lie to a FISA judge.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Unverifiable information, that's perjury. And if you want to be OK with perjury that's fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You think the FBI lied to the FISA judges?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We actually have evidence.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: By the way, America, unverified information on the warrant application.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, America, four Republican FISA judges who saw repeated requests from the FBI and granted them all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he's been indicted for anything? Is he a Russian agent, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. Carter Page doesn't really strike me as a really brilliant.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I mean, if Carter Page has a security clearance, it must be revoked immediately. Getting back to that topic of security clearances, the system for security clearance actually needs to be cleaned up significantly. I think there are valid questions about why senior officials get to keep their security clearances. When you look at what the administration is accusing these former officials, two of them who work for Trump, Comey and McCabe, of doing in terms of politicizing this, they see it as an interference with the nation's business and interference of the office of the presidency. And if you look just the twitter feed of John Brennan, James Clapper, Susan Rice, they're not just talking about disagreements in terms of foreign policy. They're talking about why aren't Republican speaking out? Susan rice is tweeting all about getting out the vote against Republicans. James Comey just this week saying if you want to save America, you have to vote for Democrats in the fall. So, there is a question about whether people who want to engage in those kinds of politics really should have access to top-secret information at the highest levels of our government when they may not be getting briefed directly by the administration, but they could still be talking to people inside those agencies and getting information to further their political goals.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think the point here is that they have credibility and that people might listen to them.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: James Clapper has credibility?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Lied to the American public repeatedly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Director of National Intelligence because he was.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And he lied under oath.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm just telling you, I think that Trump wants to undermine the entire intelligence community.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, they did that to themselves. The media anointing a new front runner to take on President Trump in 2020, does his potential opponent stand a chance? Find out next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, Democrats still searching for their new leader and the person to take on Donald Trump in 2020. Elizabeth Warren, the senator, is featured on the cover of the latest issue of New York Magazine, she's being billed as the current Democratic front runner, also leader of the persistence. Meanwhile, in my latest column in The Hill, I'm arguing Democrats should be focusing on white working-class voters to defeat Donald Trump. I'm going to go to a white working-class -- you're not working class. I forgot. A white rich voter. I'm sorry, Mr. Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Richer now that the Trump tax cuts kicked in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not in New York.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, listen to the grumbling. There's grumbling at the table. OK, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, here's the thing, Elizabeth Warren, on the cover, Elizabeth Warren stands for single-payer health care, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Warren wants to help young people who have heavy tuition debt coming out of college. She thinks a minimum wage hike could be a good idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How do you, as a white working class American, feels about this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen, I think she's got a good shot of getting the nomination. I think the base likes her. I think she can excite a crowd. She's younger than Biden. And, you know, she's female. She's exciting. And, you know, I think she also has a lot of negatives. The Pocahontas thing is going to kill her. She's got an identity crisis there that I think that name stuck and it cuts and it hurts and it went viral. She hasn't been able to get over it. There's the phony factor which is a problem. I don't know if she can play nationally being a Northeastern liberal. I don't know if she plays in a North Carolina, or an Arizona, or a place like that. She's got absolutely no Wall Street support. And, as a Democrat, I know you play footsie with Wall Street. You want to bash them, you know, out in public, but then behind the scenes you want to ask for their money and gravel. But Wall Street hates her. I don't think they're going to pay her a lot of money during the campaign. And she's open borders, she's pro-tax hikes, so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Hang on. You know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's read the file.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He might. But.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I created the file.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that right? They pay the Republicans, you want them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm saying she's not going to get a lot of Wall Street donations compared to some other Democrats, like Obama, who talked a big game about cracking down on Wall Street and then did absolutely nothing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, Katie, who is your pick for the Democratic nomination?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm not going to pick someone. But if they want Elizabeth Warren to run -- first of all, she was wearing sandals in that picture. If you're going to run a marathon like a presidential election, you better put some good running shoes on. The second thing is she always acts like she's so pro-middle-class worker when she is one of the most elitist people that they have in the senate. She can't relate to anybody. She's similar to Hillary Clinton that way. And when it comes to her policy, she's always talking on the surface level about bringing back middle-class jobs, fighting for the little guy, but actually the thing that she votes for and supports like minimum wage hikes and not taking down Dodd-Frank, actually bring robots in to take minimum-wage jobs that people can then get into and then build their careers from there. And it actually hurts small businesses that can't get small business loans to further their ambitions. So her policies don't actually match up with her working-class rhetoric. And I'm not sure that she has enough intersectionality, just like Joe Biden, to make it on the far left.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What does that mean? Intersectionality?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: She's too white. She's not diverse enough, even though she pretends to be a minority. And so the far left of the party now isn't really going to take someone like that. They need someone with more of those boxes checked.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Dana, one group that we've seen slide a little bit in the Trump universe are white suburban women.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that they're a little uncomfortable with separating children from parents and the like.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I would say a couple things. It's kind of the tale of two midterms. So you have in the House the president really needs to try to keep some independence in his corner so that he can help keep the House. But in the Senate, to keep the Senate, he really needs his base to get out, Republicans to turn out. So in some ways the polls today is not that instructive on that. Independents, if those women decide not to vote for him in the midterm, then the House might go. But I think also for this one, for Democrats going forward, they've learned lessons over and over, and so have Republicans. Voters always want what they can't have. In 2012, Republicans were begging Chris Christie to run. He didn't. He chose to run in 2016, and now his moment has passed. And I think that is the same for Elizabeth Warren. That in 2016, she would've had the whole left wing to herself. And she would have eclipsed Bernie Sanders. But she decided to endorse Hillary Clinton, and now there's so much energy and so much attention on the left that her time has probably passed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You really think so. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I think you neglected to point out that New York Magazine, that's their comedy issue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They hired --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Once a year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Once a year do it. They have all this stuff written by the morons at TIME magazine. And that's what they got. You know, this is why the focus is going to be on ousting Trump. Because they've got nothing to beat him with but himself. And so that's why they've been shouting about impeachment. It's like rather than compete against Trump, they'd rather, like, flip the board over, turn it over, because he's beating them in Monopoly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This is so true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He will make it a choice, not a referendum.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He will say, like, "You could have a sitting president who's overseeing a roaring economy --"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: "-- or you could have somebody who believes in socialism. I mean, you pick."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. So as long as the economy does well, they're screwed. And Comey actually said something right. He told the Democrats, "You've got to get a grip." Right? Don't be so crazy. Because at the pace of this demonization, they're so -- they demonize at -- it's incredible. Every day, it gets worse. They, the Dems will be no different than, like, the drug-addled maniac on the street corner who's shouting that asteroids are coming, and he forgot to wear his pants.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You mentioned something about the economy doing well. I had a buddy who was out at the Four Seasons brunch in Beverly Hills and ran into --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I said white working-class, didn't I?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Funny that you mention that, Juan. Guess who he ran into? Maxine Waters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: At the $100-a-head --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She's -- yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- brunch of Four Seasons. And he was talking to her for a while.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You couldn't eat that much brunch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And she admitted to him that Trump will win in 2020, because the economy will be so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who said that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maxine Waters.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a scoop.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a scoop.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It is, right now. Happening, breaking. Jesse's got it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you guys believe it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Aww.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Comedian Michelle Wolf, hot water for her again. This time, for comparing ICE agents to ISIS terrorists. The video -- amazing -- coming up on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hollywood continues to lash out against President Trump and his administration. Comedian Chelsea Handler once again going after the president.

utterances.speaker: CHELSEA HANDLER, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: My fantasy is to see Donald Trump dragged out of the White House in his boxer shorts. You know, with his little hair --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No, Chelsea, no.

utterances.speaker: HANDLER
utterances.sentences: And landing in the Rose Garden. You know what I mean? I want him naked and humiliated.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, hilarious. And Michelle Wolf making an outrageous comparison between ICE and terrorists.

utterances.speaker: MICHELLE WOLF, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: It's popular nowadays to say ICE is bad, but there's no better representation of American values right now than ICE is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: ICE is waging war for everything that's holy in this country. I guess you could call it a holy war.

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: Take it from me. No organization is better than ICE is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: ISIS!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, I don't think that's funny at all. Greg, will this work with a certain segment of people?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She is -- Michelle Wolf right now is in a lot of hot water comparing ICE to ISIS, because they feel that it insulted ISIS. I guess this is what time does. These people forget the journalists and the innocent people whose heads were cut off. And that's what we dealt with for four years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: While here -- I mean, at -- we were sitting here at this table to have to go through -- it was horrible. We don't think about that that much anymore, and we should. You know, right now, Trump is a character in their movie. He's a bad character. He's not just wrong. He's evil. You can never quote Krauthammer enough. He always said the difference between the left and right is we think they're misguided or stupid, but they think we're evil.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Evil. Katie, what do you think about that in terms of, like, reaching a younger demographic?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I think it's just really unfortunate and disgusting. You know, there are good men and women working in ICE every single day who are just trying to feed their families and keep the country safe. And if people like Michelle Wolf and her Hollywood friends like Chelsea Handler would spend an ounce of the energy they spend demonizing good people in America, you know, demonizing people who are hurting other people, real rapists, real child traffickers, real terrorist, you might actually get somewhere. And to reiterate Greg's point, you know, we still have men and women in Afghanistan who are still dying as a result of us being there to stop ISIS. We still have a presence in Iraq and Syria as a result of this. Because those people are there to make sure that we are not hurt here at home. And so, reaching -- you know, I guess I would be in the younger demographic. It doesn't sit well with me. I don't think it's funny, first of all. So if this is supposed to be comedy, they need to work on it. But just overall, the dehumanization of good people who are literally putting their lives on the line every single day so that people like Michelle Wolf and Chelsea Handler can live in their own elitist bubble every single day, I just think it's pretty disgusting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's not like there isn't other things for them to make fun of, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There's so much to make fun of.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jesse's hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not that. I just want to know, how did Rove get on a panel with Chelsea Handler?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, what has happened to Karl Rove.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's that thing where they try to -- it's called OZYFest, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That thing where they try to get a bunch of different people --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Got it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- and the goal is to get a whole bunch of different people together to show that we can agree.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're the complete opposites. I'm not sure they did agree. So I don't know what came of that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Karl didn't seem like he was very comfortable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. It was weird that she said she wanted to see the president naked. I found that odd. The whole abolish ICE thing, I think the Democrats are just abolishing their chances of winning in the midterms. This happened back during the Iraq War when they attacked our troops. That hurt them politically. A couple years ago, the Democrats went after police very hard. I think that hurt them politically. And they're just walking into another brick wall with his anti-ICE stuff, and it's really so far out of the mainstream of American society, I can't believe they don't even see it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Boy, you guys are out of touch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, tell me. Because I wondered that. I'm know that it offends me. That's why I was sort of asking. Does it work for other audiences?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it does. I think that you have to understand that people who see children being separated from their parents, people who are trying to do their jobs and see, you know, gardeners being raided and pushed out, because, "Oh, you look like you're Hispanic." People feel like they're being terrorized. But the larger point is this is not an attack on the men and women who work for ICE. This is an attack on people who have made ICE into a deportation force, who have made ICE into suddenly, you know -- I'm reminded of what people used -- on the right used to say about ATF. You know, jackbooted thugs coming to grab your guns. This is the way lots of people in the Latino, immigrant community --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You agree comparing them to ISIS terrorists is a step too far?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I said --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- they feel like terrorists. But I'm telling you this is not an attack on the people --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Is ICE cutting people's heads off? Is ICE cutting people's heads off, Juan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's not an attack.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's an attack on the people. It's an attack on the policy, Greg. The policy that would use them in this way to separate people --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They compared them to ISIS. They actually --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The idea is -- I mean, this is what Michelle Wolf got into trouble with at the Correspondents' Dinner.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: She's being edgy, and I think she has every right to be edgy. But a lot of people are uncomfortable, especially guess what? The people who are being zinged by her humor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But it's like when Comey says they need to get a grip. I think that's part -- I mean, it's not going to win back white working-class voters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know, but --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let them do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- it's not going to -- it is going to excite people who are pi -- angry.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: ICE agents are working-class voters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oop, oop. We almost had a bleepable moment. All right, our bucket list facing a midlife crisis. Why the popular life- planning tool may be flatlining. Next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Great song.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It seems like almost everyone has a list of dreams they'd like to fulfill before they die. Perhaps swimming with sharks -- one of mine -- or going on an African safari -- also one of mine -- or even jumping out of a plane, just like I did right there. But is it time to kick the bucket list? An op-ed in The Wall Street Journal argues that these lists serve as a shortcut and cheap substitutes for not being more adventurous earlier in life. So, Dana, this author, Joe --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It must be because I'm so young.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, but can't you have a bucket life -- a bucket list throughout your life? Like, I don't see it as an end-of-life thing, where, like, "I'm going to die, and now I have to check off these ten things."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that it becomes, like, a lot of pressure, then, thinking about all the things you want to do before you die, like, as a bucket list thing. I think it's, like, a kind of interesting concept. I think older people are doing it now, because their path was to work really hard in their 20s, and they did things in this order. Like, school, marriage, job, kids. And then college, and then retirement. And they can do these things. And I think that it's kind of flipped now. Like, younger people want to have these experiences now. And it's like, they're delaying things until they get to have their gap years or things like that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I think experiences are also more assessable now, Juan, with things that we have available in the world just because of the way that the economies have worked and improved.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So I think this was a Joe Queenan piece in the Saturday Journal. And what struck me about it was that at some point, he says, you know, "Enough with the bucket list. I mean, let's move on. If you really want to do something, like, you know, that's different, go help somebody. Go volunteer. Go actually make a difference in the world." And I was struck by that. I thought that's a pretty powerful message.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But Greg, isn't this something that you would have written?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Absolutely. Well, Joe Queenan is almost always right. And I can tell you, as a writer and a journalist in men's magazine, the bucket list was never really a thing. No one ever made a list. This was a device created for freelance writers to write adventure and travel pieces for magazines like AARP or Men's Journal or Men's Life. It was just a way to make money. So they go, "Oh, let's do something on bucket lists. That means I can go do Outward Bound in Colorado. I can go climb Everest." I have what I call the reverse bucket list in which I'm trying to remove stupid behavior from my past. I don't want to add things. I want to remove things.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's like the bucket has no bottom if you are one of those journalists. It's kind of smart.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It doesn't have a starting point, right, Jesse? I mean, I'm sure your bucket list started in the womb. Amazing things happening in your life.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I've had a lot of crazy, dangerous experiences growing up and now I want to avoid them. I don't want to swim with sharks. I don't want to skydive. I don't want to run with the bulls. I don't want to do any of that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Sounds really lame.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I want to sit on a beach, have a drink and relax. That's all I want to do.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: What about the accusation in this essay that, if you have a bucket list of adventure, it's just basically a pathetic way of compensating for things you have not done earlier?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think it's for boring people that want to not be boring.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Are you saying that I'm boring?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And tell everybody all these crazy things they did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I disagree. I think that there are people out there who worked really, really hard. They put their kids through college. They -- maybe they helped their parents at their end-of-life, now they have some time and they want to do some things while they are still healthy enough to do them, so they create this bucket list.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, have you been to the beach this summer? You see all these, like, older people with tattoos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bo, no, no. It is absolutely amazing. It was -- I have -- I was in Hawaii. Everybody has tattoos. This is now -- it's now the minority, you don't have tattoos.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that is part of the bucket list. I think they're like - - somebody people hit 17, "You know what? I'm getting a tattoo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I always wanted a bucket list.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tattoos do not look good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I didn't want to say it, but --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A friend of mine's dad always wanted an earring and couldn't because of the place that he worked. And so now he has one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's unbelievable?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Are these fresh tattoos or are these older tattoos?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not getting into it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? A lot a tattoos are just bad tattoos. A lot of people get bad tattoos.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, like "Hillary 2016."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Katie, let -- you have to answer the question. Why are you jumping out of airplanes?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Because it's fun. It's not just a bucket list thing. Because why not? Life is too short. YOLO. That's the millennial --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Almost too short, because she forgot to pull the rip cord.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I was about to say. I was about to say.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I almost -- I almost had a short -- a shortened life, because I didn't pull the chute. But it wasn't my job. It was only a suggestion. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "OMT" -- J.W.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Greg has been on a new diet. And he looks great. He's really slimmed down and trimmed it up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And but he had a moment of weakness where we caught him with his proverbial hand in the cookie jar. Here he is right here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He climbed on top of a little countertop. There he is. Reaching in for a doughnut but was caught red-handed and had to put it back. Sorry, Greg. There it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's your "One More Thing"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's my "One More Thing." It's from all the hair jokes. I had to get him back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was nice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That Greg was a chubby little guy.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Eating doughnuts all day.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. You've heard about people popping out of cakes at bachelor parties, but how about a big surprise at the wedding? Johnny Campbell, an Alabama football fan, got married to Becca Campbell, who's a Louisiana State football fan. So she gave him a cake with an Alabama "A" on top during the wedding reception. But watch what happens when he cuts into it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: LSU! LSU!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: LSU! LSU!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: LSU! LSU!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It was purple and gold inside, the colors of LSU. I think my man lost his appetite.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Got him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's crazy stuff. All right. It's time for something new.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Foreign Policy with Animals

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Foreign Policy with Animals." So I asked a dog and some bunnies if they could reenact president -- reenact President Obama's foreign policy. So let's check it out here. It's just -- there he is with a bunch of carrots, feeding these rabbits. He never -- you know, it took a while. They were, like, actually

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Can I get in on that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Taking the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The rabbits and their pigs. There's a pig in there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That dog is very patient.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he is. Yes. And you know what? He's just giving away the carrots. You don't see a stick anywhere. No sticks anywhere, Dana. That's the foreign policy of President Obama! All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Trained to feed them carrots?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Isn't that beautiful? Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. I'm going to promote Greg's book today.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ah, yay!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's called "The Gutfeld Monologues," and it comes out tomorrow. And I interviewed him today on the "Fox News Rundown" podcast. It's going to air tomorrow morning, so you should subscribe to that on anywhere you can like iTunes, Apple podcast, Google Play. Go to FoxNewsRundown.com. You can download it. It was pretty fun to interview him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was a good -- you did a good interview.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You did a good interview. You know, she did -- I didn't know what to expect.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've had a chance to read through it. It's an excellent book. If you have been a fan of "The Five," if you've watched his monologues, you're going to love it. It's a little bit of a trip down memory lane, but he goes back and he critiques himself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And he's honest about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's pretty funny about it, and I encourage everyone to buy it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Which one was your favorite monologue?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love all the ones -- oh, gosh, I have a few. I told him in the interview that I'm his personal laugh track. But I really do love it when you come up with like the peanut helmet thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. The peanut helmet.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All the little jokes for Dana are pretty funny.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's really good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I think -- I think, by the way, there's big credit to be given to Greg for the idea that he would go back over time and say, "Maybe this was a little off."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would never do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, there's -- I had no choice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I thought you said that about the haircut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I had no choice. All right. Katie, what you got?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Mine is really sad and a tragedy, but also hilarious. Who doesn't love a scoop of guacamole or spicy salsa on a crisp tortilla chip?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Love it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Lots of people. But these chips that these that these people are not eating, these other chips, brought the heat because firefighters were called to a Texas tortilla chip not once but twice in three days after boxes of chips spontaneously combusted.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Both fires started when the tortilla chip factory was testing a new way to handle chip waste. Who throws tortillas away?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. Chip waste, what's that?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The Austin Fire Department said they were distressed to be called out to a tortilla chip warehouse twice to battle the fire, writing in a Facebook quote -- Facebook post, "Tortillas chips are big business around these parts. We take them very seriously, as they are responsible for holding all manner of very important things like queso, salsa, nachos and various other sun-dried items that are critical to a Texan's everyday life and well-being." So they are very sad that these chips spontaneously combusted.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Terrible.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And I'm sure there were lots of Austin residents who also are very sad. But after the two fires, the firefighters had no choice but to drown out the rest of the chips in the warehouse to make sure the risk was completely taken away.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow. Terrible.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So there might be a chip shortage in Texas, which is not good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe they can get some from somewhere else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Trade.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent. All right, he's bringing us the news, and he's willing to share. Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Bret Baier. "Special Report" is up next. Hey, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: You're going to run out of them. Thanks, Greg. Copy: Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
